name: Linux Development and Desktop Environment Features
description: A comprehensive collection of features and tools for software development, desktop environment customization, system compatibility, and graphical interface support in Linux. This parent feature includes frameworks, libraries, tools, and compatibility layers necessary for creating diverse applications and configuring graphical environments tailored to user needs. It also encompasses tiling and traditional window managers, programming language-specific development tools, and accessibility to ensure an inclusive and robust Linux ecosystem.

name: System Tools and Management Utilities
description: A comprehensive collection of tools and utilities designed to support various system-level tasks, administration, performance optimization, security enhancement, debugging, and network management. This parent feature encompasses a wide range of functionalities tailored for users managing complex systems, from desktop environments to large-scale enterprise servers, headless systems, and virtual environments. These tools provide the necessary capabilities for system configuration, hardware monitoring, security auditing, performance tuning, and ensuring efficient operations across diverse computing environments.

name: Desktop Environments and Applications
description: A comprehensive collection of desktop environments, their associated applications, and supplementary features to provide a full suite of tools for user interaction, productivity, multimedia, office tasks, and entertainment. This parent feature includes various lightweight and feature-rich desktop environments, such as GNOME, KDE, LXDE, LXQt, Xfce, MATE, and Deepin, along with respective applications and utilities tailored to maximize their functionality. It also encompasses multimedia support, office suites, translations, games, plugins, and additional tools to enhance the overall desktop user experience.

name: Infrastructure and Service Management
description: This feature encompasses a comprehensive set of tools and software suites designed to provide key infrastructure services and manage server functionalities. From centralized backup and directory management to cloud computing and high availability, these features enable system administrators to build, secure, and optimize server infrastructure. It includes support for network services like DNS, email, file sharing, and load balancing, as well as additional roles such as identity management, printing, and web hosting. This enables robust management of mission-critical components and seamless integration into diverse environments while supporting legacy protocols, cloud-based systems, and advanced data-storage configurations.

name: Development and Software Deployment Ecosystem
description: This parent feature encompasses a comprehensive ecosystem of tools, platforms, and frameworks designed to support software development, programming languages, application servers, database management systems, and web development. It integrates support for a variety of programming languages, databases, runtime environments, and development tools that enable seamless application development, deployment, and management. The ecosystem provides essential resources for developers to create, test, and deploy software across multiple programming paradigms and platforms, while also supporting database systems to manage application data efficiently.

name: Comprehensive Software and Tools Ecosystem
description: A broad collection of software and tools designed to meet diverse user needs spanning creative, scientific, educational, administrative, system-level, and professional domains. This feature encompasses applications for 3D printing, network management, text editing, graphics creation, engineering simulations, audio production, educational tools, robotics, technical writing, hardware support, and much more. It provides a unified package that caters to users from various fields including designers, developers, engineers, scientists, educational instructors, and system administrators.

name: Linux Deployment and Virtualization Ecosystem
description: This parent feature encapsulates a comprehensive range of functionalities aimed at deploying, managing, and running Linux environments in various deployment scenarios, including virtualization, cloud computing, and containerized applications. It includes tools and packages required for basic Linux installations, cloud infrastructure tools, virtualization management, container orchestration, and platform-specific optimization. The ecosystem supports both headless and graphical environments, as well as remote and hypervisor-based management interfaces.

name: Linux Product Core and Conflict Management
description: This parent feature encompasses the foundational and conflict management packages necessary for various Linux products and installation scenarios. It includes mandatory package groups ensuring support for specific product types such as Atomic Host (ostree-based), Linux Client, ComputeNode, Server, and Workstation products. Furthermore, it addresses ostree support for Workstation and Atomic Host environments. In addition, this feature outlines groups of packages that are known to conflict with @everything installations for specific product variants (Client, ComputeNode, Server, and Workstation) as well as conflicting packages from AppStream and BaseOS repositories.

name: Critical Path Framework
description: The Critical Path Framework encompasses all components, applications, and packages deemed essential for the proper functioning, building, installation, and delivery of Linux systems and their spins. This feature ensures that a baseline of critical functionality is consistently provided across different system roles, desktop environments, and deployment scenarios. It acts as the backbone for essential services, ranging from shared platform capabilities to specialized desktop and server editions, as well as build and compose processes. The Critical Path Framework guarantees a robust foundation for system interaction, stability, and extensibility, regardless of the spin or functional context.
